Column Comment.0: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema.
Column Comment.1: TABLE NAME: The name of the table within the schema.
Column Comment.2: COLUMN NAME: Name of the column within a specific table found in the PPDMschema
Column Comment.3: AUDIT ROW GUID: In order to use this table, you must have the PPDM GUIDcolumns in the table to be audited in use, with the NOT NULL constraints turned on,and a unique index on the PPDM GUID column. In this table, the AUDIT ROW GUIDis the GUID for the row that is being audited.
Column Comment.4: AUDIT SEQUENCE NUMBER: a number that is used to order the occurence ofauditable changes to values in the database.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: AUDIT AUTHORIZED BY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFER: Unique identifier forthe business associate who authorized an auditable change to be made to a recordin the database.
Column Comment.7: AUDIT CHANGE CREATED BY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Uniqueidentifier for the business associate who created the audit record.
Column Comment.8: AUDIT DATETIME: the system or user date and time when this audit is considered tobe in effect.
Column Comment.9: AUDIT DESCRIPTION: Narrative descriptive comments about the transaction thatchanged the data, such as comments about the data source or method used, abusiness rule used for the transaction etc.
Column Comment.10: AUDIT REASON: The reason why an auditable change was made to the data, suchas data cleanup project, new data received, incorrect data corrected, missing datalocated etc.
Column Comment.11: AUDIT SOURCE: use this column to identify the source of the new information thatresulted in the creation of this audit record.
Column Comment.12: AUDIT TYPE: The type of change that is being tracked in this row of audit data.Depending on the business rules in place, may track inserts, updates or deletes.
Column Comment.13: AUDIT VERIFIED BY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: unique identifier whoquality controlled and verified the auditable change to a value in the database.
Column Comment.14: DATATYPE: The database "type" for the column. Oracle uses DATE, NUMBER,VARCHAR2, LONG and so on.
Column Comment.15: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.16: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.17: NEW DATE VALUE: the new value of the column for this GUID identified row of data,where the original data type was in date format.
Column Comment.18: NEW NUMERIC VALUE: the new value of the column for this GUID identified row ofdata, where the original data type was in number format.
Column Comment.21: NEW TEXT VALUE: the new value of the column for this GUID identified row of data,where the original data type was in textual format.
Column Comment.22: NULL DESCRIPTION: If this value is NULL, a narrative descrption about why it is null(not available, historical records damaged or lost etc).
Column Comment.23: ORIGINAL DATE VALUE: the original value of the column for this GUID identifiedrow of data, where the original data type was in date format.
Column Comment.24: ORIGINAL NUMERIC VALUE: the original value of the column for this GUIDidentified row of data, where the original data type was in number format.
Column Comment.27: ORIGINAL TEXT VALUE: the original value of the column for this GUID identified rowof data, where the original data type was in textual format.
Column Comment.28: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.29: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.30: RETENTION PERIOD: The length of time records or materials should be kept in acertain location or form for administrative, legal, fiscal, historical, or other purposes.Retention periods are determined by balancing the potential value of the informationto the agency against the costs of storing the records containing that information.Retention periods are often set for record series, but specific records within thatseries may need to be retained longer because they are required for litigation orbecause circumstances give those records unexpected archival value.
Column Comment.31: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row. In this case, identifies the source of the AUDIT rowof data.
Column Comment.32: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.33: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.34: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.35: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.36: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.37: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.38: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
